Linearity

One of the useful properties of sigma notation is that we can combine series using the property of linearity. Formally we have the following:


If \(c\) is any constant (i.e. does not depend on \(n\)), then \[ \sum_{n=a}^{b} cx_n =c\sum_{n=a}^{b} x_n \] and \[ \sum_{n=a}^{b} (x_n+y_n)=\sum_{n=a}^{b} x_n+\sum_{n=a}^{b} y_n. \]

Another useful property (just like when we worked with definite integrals) is that we can split a sum up into parts:

If \(a,b,c\) are integers with \(a<b<c\) then \[\sum_{n=a}^{c} x_n=\sum_{n=a}^{b} x_n+\sum_{n=b+1}^{c} x_n.\]
